bioghist.p: Martha Carey Thomas (1857-1935) received her bachelor's degree from Cornell University in 1877. She did graduate work at Johns Hopkins University, the University of Leipzig, and the University of Zurich where she earned a Ph.D. in linguistics, in 1882. In 1884, Thomas became dean of the college and chair of English at the new Bryn Mawr College for women. In 1894, the first president of the college, James Rhoads, retired, and Thomas was narrowly elected to succeed him. She was president until 1922 and remained as Dean until 1908. In 1908, she became the first president of the National College Women's Equal Suffrage League. She was also a leading member of the National American Woman Suffrage Association. After 1920 she advocated the policies of the National Woman's Party. She was one of the early promoters of an equal rights amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Thomas lived for many years in a close relationship with her friend and housemate Mamie Gwinn. After Gwinn left Thomas in 1904 to marry, Thomas took up housekeeping with the philanthropist Mary Garrett, with whom Thomas shared the campus home, living together until Garrett's death. Thomas died in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She is buried on the Bryn Mawr College campus in the cloisters of the Thomas Library.

scopecontent.p: This collection includes documents pertinent to the settlement of M. Carey Thomas's estate. In addition, there are accounts and other records relative to the estates of Mary E. Garrett and Edith Lowber, Garrett County, Maryland, properties, and to the Thomas family summer cottage, Coombe Edge.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Bryn Mawr College: M. Carey Thomas papers and Mary E. Garrett papers.
